Guest Speakers

  • Danielle Artis
  • James Darius Ball
  • Karl Egloff
  • Katy Fenn
  • Megan Franci
  • Evan Freund
  • Leigh Henry
  • Nilanga Jayasinghe
  • Dr. Nelly Kadagi
  • Debra Kathman
  • Jessica Leung
  • Sammi Lin
  • Loren Mayor
  • Julie S. Miller
  • Dr. Robin Naidoo
  • Kyle Newman
  • Alex Nichols-Vinueza
  • Carter Roberts
  • Niccola Somers
  • Peter Umunay
  • Anita van Breda
  • Andrew Wiley
  • Katie Zdilla

Andrew Wiley, Director, Partners in Conservation, WWF-US

Andrew leads the fundraising strategy and communications plan to connect WWF's Partners in Conservation community with its global conservation mission. He oversees the strategic direction of this program to increase the support and engagement of these committed annual donors through mailings, digital platforms, personal correspondence, and in-person events and webinars. He is also responsible for the personal stewardship and meaningful cultivation of Partners, and manages the WWF staff who build relationships with select conservation-minded donors who are closest to the organization. Andrew is a member of the Director Marketing Fundraisers Association's board of directors, and is a convenor and co-facilitator of its Mid-Level Giving Summit. Before joining WWF in 2009, Andrew worked in the development offices at the National Council for the Traditional Arts, Washington National Opera, and Common Cause. Originally from St. Paul, Minnesota, Andrew earned a BFA from Syracuse University. In his spare time, he can be found on stage singing lead vocals for DC's Finest Blues-Fiddle Band, The Roustabouts.

Julie S. Miller, Executive Vice President, Philanthropic Partnerships and Board Relations, WWF-US

Julie leads WWF’s private fundraising efforts, providing critical support to its conservation initiatives around the world. Additionally, she also offers strategic management to the WWF-US Board of Directors and National Council and has been instrumental in the establishment of multi-stakeholder partnerships to achieve conservation at-scale.

Julie joined WWF in 2008 with over 25 years of relationship management and governance experience. During her professional career she has developed and managed The World Bureau, a research and information product development firm, and was also Group Vice President of Commercial Lending at the First American Bank of Washington.

Julie has brought her considerable governance and advancement expertise to several nonprofit boards. She is an alumna of the University of Kansas and the George Washington University and has also completed an executive management program at the University of Pennsylvania’s Wharton School of Business.

Carter Roberts, President and CEO, WWF-US

Carter Roberts has served as President and CEO of World Wildlife Fund in the United States since 2000. During that time, he's built a wide-reaching program on corporate sustainability, pioneered performance-based financial instruments for national protected area systems, and helped reverse the decline in tiger, rhino, and elephant populations in key parts of the world. As founding chair of Enduring Earth, Carter helped create a partnership with other NGOs and investors to strengthen the conservation of over a billion hectares of land. He founded Boundless Conservation Fellowship, a network of next generation conservation leaders and leading specialists key to conserving the whole of landscapes and seascapes. His work extends to WWF Impact, which invests in entrepreneurs developing innovative technologies to food systems challenges through sustainable practices in seaweed cultivation, food waste reduction, and regenerative agriculture. Carter has learned the calls of all the birds in North America. He serves on the boards of the Nicholas Institute at Duke University and the Grantham Institute for Climate Change. He holds an MBA from Harvard Business School and a BA from Princeton University.

Dr. Nelly Kadagi, Director, Conservation Leadership and Russell E Train Education for Nature Program, WWF-US

Nelly oversees and manages WWF’s strategy for conservation capacity development and leadership. Originally from Kenya, Nelly brings a wealth of expertise to WWF, spanning scientific program development, marine conservation support, fundraising, and designing capacity-building initiatives in Africa and North America. In her role, Nelly helps to ensure conservation leaders have access to the education and resources needed to address global environmental challenges.

Previously, Nelly worked as a postdoctoral research fellow at the University of Denver and One Earth Future–Secure Fisheries. . Nelly also served as the Director of Research for the African Billfish Foundation where she championed billfish research across the Western Indian Ocean.

In addition to now leading the EFN program, Nelly is an EFN alumna. She received a Russell E. Train Fellowship in 2015 that supported her PhD studies while at the University of Florida. She is also a Schlumberger Faculty for the Future Fellow, a New England Aquarium Marine Conservation and Action Fund Fellow, and a recipient of the Conservation Leadership Program Award.

Dr. Peter Umunay, Senior Environmental Specialist, Global Environment Facility (GEF)

Peter is an EFN alumni who received a Russell E. Train Fellowship to pursue his PhD in 2015. Peter is now the Global Thematic Lead for Food Systems and Land Use at the GEF. He manages Agri-food system programs and provides strategic oversight over seven GEF Integrated Programs (IPs), leading a team of IP leads and technical experts, ensuring the seamless integration of programming efforts, knowledge sharing, and learning activities. His work supports GEF's mission to deliver global environmental benefits across multiple focal areas (biodiversity, climate change, land degradation and pollution).

Peter brings over 15 years of experience working with international organizations—including the Wildlife Conservation Society, The Forests Dialogue, UNEP-WCMC, UNEP, and Winrock International—as well as with academic institutions, research organizations, and government agencies. Peter has over 30 scientific publications and works in collaboration with scientists across the world in the areas of the forest-climate nexus. He holds a BSc from Kisangani University (DRC), and MSc and PhD from the Yale School of Forestry and Environmental Studies

Katie Zdilla, Senior Director of Durable Conservation and Finance, WWF-US

Katie is the Senior Director of Durable Conservation and Finance and works to catalyze long-term, sustainable financing for large-scale conservation areas. She leads the development of emerging Project Finance for Permanence opportunities for WWF with Enduring Earth and drives protected and conserved area innovation and research in areas where WWF can make strategic investments for outsized impact. This includes collaborating to ensure protected and conserved areas are more inclusive, resilient, and durable. Katie has a Master’s in Sustainable Development and Conservation Biology and a Bachelor’s in Biology with a minor in Environmental Studies. Outside of her formal education, she has additional training from the Organization for Tropical Studies and the University of The Gambia. A native of the DC metro area, she grew up volunteering at the National Zoo where she first built relationships with some of the species that she now works to protect.

Debra Kathman, Senior Director of Gift Planning, WWF-US

Debra is the Senior Director of Gift Planning. She oversees a staff of 9, with the gift planning effort here at WWF responsible for marketing, soliciting and closing current planned gifts, as well as working with attorneys and executors to ensure WWF receives realized bequest gifts promptly. During her tenure at WWF, the gift planning effort has grown considerably, more than doubling marketing inquiries, Legacy Circle membership and bequest income, which is now the largest source of unrestricted income to WWF. Debra began her career as a trust and estates attorney before transitioning to fundraising. Before joining WWF in 2016, Debra worked in similar roles at organizations such as the American Diabetes Association, the American Red Cross and the National Wildlife Federation.

Karl Egloff, Director, Travel, Tourism & Conservation Program, WWF-US

For over 10 years, Karl has been the Director of WWF’s Travel, Tourism & Conservation Program. He oversees WWF’s close relationship with Natural Habitat Adventures to collaborate on marketing and operating nature-focused travel programs for WWF supporters. He grew up in Alaska before attending Montana State University and later started his career guiding and managing travel programs around the world. After settling in the Washington DC area, he received a Master of Tourism Administration from The George Washington University.

Leigh Henry, Director, Wildlife Policy, Wildlife Conservation, WWF-US

Leigh is a conservationist and policy expert guided by a lifelong love for wildlife and wild places and a desire to preserve them for future generations. Leigh started her career working for famed oceanographer Jacques Cousteau, where she was inspired to pursue a degree in environmental law to further her work in international wildlife conservation. Since joining WWF in 2001, Leigh has played a key role in efforts to combat wildlife crime and was a core member of the WWF’s Stop Wildlife Crime campaign, which secured unprecedented global and US leadership to end poaching and illegal wildlife trade. In her current role, Leigh leads WWF’s jaguar conservation program, is a member of the global tiger conservation team supporting efforts to stop illegal tiger trade, and leads WWF’s whale conservation efforts.

Robin Naidoo, Lead Scientist for Wildlife Conservation, WWF-US

Dr. Robin Naidoo is an internationally recognized applied scholar who investigates the ecological and economic issues that impact wildlife conservation. His work, from mapping ecosystem services to monitoring animal migrations, places nature at the center of sustainable development and helps support a future where species and people coexist.

Robin's current research is largely focused on understanding the interaction between biodiversity and people, particularly in field-based contexts in Africa. In southern Africa's Kavango-Zambezi transfrontier conservation area, Robin has used satellite collars to document a migration of Burchell’s Zebra across Namibia and Botswana, highlighting the importance of transboundary conservation in this region. He also works on the movement ecology and migratory behavior of other species in this region, including elephants and African buffalo. He holds an interdisciplinary PhD in conservation biology and environmental economics and is an Adjunct Professor at the University of British Columbia and the University of Vermont.

Megan Franci, Gift Planning Specialist, WWF-US

In her role as Gift Planning Specialist, Megan supports WWF’s expanding gift planning program by developing and coordinating stewardship efforts for Legacy Circle members. She also serves as the main contact for the administration and management of WWF’s life income gifts program. Prior to WWF, Megan worked as an international teacher in Honduras, Thailand, and Italy, where she discovered a passion for education shaped by diverse cultures and educational systems and the joy of connecting with students around the world. Megan holds a bachelor's in marketing from Tulane University and a master’s in international development from Concordia University-Portland.

Danielle Artis, Philanthropy Manager, Partners in Conservation, WWF-US

Danielle is a passionate leader with over a decade of experience in philanthropic efforts. As the Philanthropy Manager for the Partners in Conservation program at WWF, she has been instrumental in advancing donor relations and strategic fundraising to safeguard vital ecosystems. Since joining WWF in 2017, Danielle has progressed through key roles, demonstrating her expertise in relationship management and resource development. Her prior experience includes nearly seven years at The Washington Center, where she forged strong partnerships, led business development, and managed alumni relations. Danielle holds a master’s in public administration from American University, a BA in history from Arizona State University, and completed the Institute for Leaders in Development program at the University of Denver. She actively contributes to the nonprofit sector, supporting various mission-driven initiatives, including her work with the Association of Fundraising Professionals, Council of Planned Giving Professionals, Animal Protection Association of Missouri, and earthday365 which supports the largest Earth Day Festival in the Midwest.

Niccola Somers, Senior Specialist, Boundless Fellowship Program, WWF-US

As Senior Specialist at WWF, Niccola works on the Boundless Conservation Fellowship. As one of the fellowship’s founding team members, she has seen the program through from its inception to implementation. Prior to WWF, Niccola spent the last decade in South America, living first in French Guiana and then Brazil. She completed her master’s in international relations at the Universidade Federal da Bahia in Salvador, Brazil, where she conducted research on human migration and illegal goldmining in the Amazon. In addition to her work at WWF, Niccola continues to teach English as a second language to international professionals, and in the summers, she volunteers on trail building projects along the Ice Age Trail in her home state of Wisconsin.

Katy Fenn, Director, Brand Engagement and Education, WWF-US

Katy Fenn is a member of WWF’s Marketing and Outreach team and has worked for WWF for almost 20 years. In her current role, she works to raise the profile of WWF’s brand and connect it to the organization’s conservation priorities. She does this by leading WWF’s Public Service Announcement campaigns, managing the strategic development and implementation of a variety of integrated marketing and communication initiatives, and running WWF’s yearly brand research. In 2017, she designed and launched Wild Classroom, an education program that aims to make conservation more relatable to young learners. Over the last eight years, Katy and her team have created resources to help educators increase the environmental literacy of youth and inspire them to drive change towards a sustainable future. Katy holds a degree in communication with a specialization in public relations and business from Michigan State University.

Jessica Leung, Director, Belonging and Employee Experience, WWF-US

As Director of Belonging and Employee Experience at WWF, Jessica oversees the organization’s strategic and programmatic initiatives to inspire and attract the next generation of conservation and environmental professionals. Jessica collaborates with stakeholders within business operations and scientific program teams, advising and leading teams on initiatives that recruit and support early career talent. Major initiatives include leading WWF’s BRIDGE paid internship program and managing partnerships with organizations such as the Smithsonian Institution. Jessica previously worked in the nonprofit and private sectors with technical expertise in decarbonizing the electricity, thermal energy, transportation, and buildings sectors. She assisted companies and government entities striving to reduce their environmental impact and convened stakeholders with policymakers to advance emissions reduction actions. Jessica earned a bachelor’s in managerial economics from the University of California, Davis and a master’s in environmental management from the Yale School of the Environment.

Sammi Lin, Program Associate, Policy and US Government Affairs, WWF-US

In her role at WWF, Sammi works to build and strengthen relationships with federal and state governments and advocates for ambitious legislation to address WWF's policy priorities. She also supports the team in tracking and pursuing US government funding opportunities to advance conservation around the world. She is a 2023 BRIDGE intern, where she worked with the Northern Great Plains team to assess how federal conservation payment programs can be made more accessible and equitable for Native ranchers. Before joining WWF, she worked with Cornell Cooperative Extension, EDF, and other NGOs and startups in Mexico, Ecuador, Vietnam, and South Africa supporting small-scale, BIPOC farmers and fishers. Originally from Queens, NYC, in her free time, she enjoys testing out new recipes, reading, studying languages, and exploring the many green spaces in DC.

Alex Nichols-Vinueza, Director, Food Loss & Waste, WWF-US

Alex supports the US Food Waste team’s portfolio of projects, including work with the agricultural, grocery retail, hospitality, and food service sectors. This includes the Global Farm Loss Tool, the Food Waste Warrior program (which empowers students to reduce their school food waste); the Zero Food Waste Coalition (which advances policies to develop a more circular food economy and mitigate climate change); and the US Food Waste Pact (which accelerates businesses’ progress toward their waste reduction targets). Alex brings over 15 years of project and partnership management experience across tech, government, and sustainability consulting in the US and Latin America. He is bilingual in Spanish and English and holds a BA from the University of Michigan and an MEM from Duke’s Nicholas School of the Environment. Alex hails from Traverse City in northern Michigan, where he grew up camping, spending summers in the area’s many parks and lakes, and working on local farms.

Loren Mayor, Chief Operating Officer, WWF-US

As Chief Operating Officer of World Wildlife Fund (WWF-US), Loren Mayor drives the organization’s strategy to create a world where people and nature live in harmony. She oversees strategic partnerships, operational functions, and resource mobilization teams while strengthening workplace culture and advancing WWF’s mission with external stakeholders.

Prior to WWF, Loren was President of Operations at National Public Radio (NPR) where she oversaw the full suite of organizational operations and identified new business opportunities, developing NPR’s strategic plan, and building a strong empowering culture. Before NPR, Loren held leadership roles at PBS, The Corporation for Public Broadcasting, and worked with clients in the non-profit and media sectors during her tenure at McKinsey & Company. Loren has an undergraduate degree from the University of Chicago, and a Ph.D. in theater from Northwestern University, where she also served as a visiting assistant professor.

James Darius Ball, Director of Future Cities, National Building Museum

James Darius Ball is the Director of Future Cities at the National Building Museum, where he leads a multi-year, interdisciplinary initiative to center the US city as hub, catalyst, essential building block of society. With a background in sustainable development, building science, and community engagement, James brings a cross-disciplinary approach to questions of urban identity and possibility. Under his leadership, Future Cities convenes exhibitions, programs, and storytelling projects that invite communities—from residents to industry leaders—to imagine cities not just as places we live, but as expressions of who we are and what we value. Prior to joining the Museum, James brought his passion for buildings to governments, developers, startups, media, and nonprofit organizations across the country. His life work is to improve the social, economic, and environmental value of our built world.

Kate Newman, Vice President, Sustainable Infrastructure and Public Sector Initiatives, WWF-US

As WWF’s vice president for sustainable infrastructure and public sector initiatives, Kate specializes in policy development and conservation planning in support of nature-positive infrastructure. For over 30 years with WWF, Kate has worked with colleagues around the world to integrate conservation science and principles into socio-economic development through terrestrial and marine natural capital and ecoregion planning, sustainable finance, green economy policies, community-based conservation, and protected area management. Pre-WWF, she supported civil society organizations in farm-to-market road, mini-hydropower, and rural clinic construction with the US Agency for International Development in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, where she was also a Peace Corps volunteer teacher. Kate received a BA in anthropology from the University of Virginia and MSc in environmental management from the University of London.

Evan Freund, Sr. Director, Sustainable Infrastructure & Finance, WWF-US

Evan is senior director for sustainable infrastructure and finance on the WWF-US Forest team. He manages programming around infrastructure design, finance, and development, including the five-year Greening Transportation Infrastructure Development (GRID) Integrated Program. Funded by the Global Environment Facility, GRID focuses on incorporating biodiversity and ecosystem-related considerations into transportation infrastructure planning.

Prior to joining WWF, Evan managed the Government and Public Sector Practice for CiBO Technologies, a venture-backed agricultural technology startup. From 2005 to 2017, Evan worked for the US government’s Millennium Challenge Corporation (MCC), a bilateral foreign aid agency. There, he designed and oversaw investments in water supply, sanitation, transportation, and energy systems in Ghana, Namibia, Honduras, and Lesotho; served as MCC’s deputy resident country director in Maputo, Mozambique; and led MCC’s programs in Liberia and the Philippines.

Evan holds a master’s degree in city planning from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and a BA from Middlebury College.

Anita van Breda, Senior Director, Environment and Disaster Management, WWF-US

Anita is Senior Director of Environment and Disaster Management at WWF based in Washington DC. She has 20 years’ experience applying environmentally responsible practices and policies for disaster recovery, reconstruction, and risk reduction.

Anita was instrumental in WWF's development of the Green Recovery and Reconstruction: Training Toolkit for Humanitarian Aid (GRRT) and leads a flood risk management guidance and training initiative on Natural and Nature-Based Flood Management.

She has collaborated with the US Army Corps of Engineers and the United Nations on nature-based approaches to disaster risk management and is co-lead of the UN Emergency Shelter Cluster Environment community of practice. She was a member of the advisory committee for the Climate and Environment Charter for Humanitarian Organizations. Anita has a master’s from the Yale School of Forestry and Environmental Studies and an undergraduate degree in Biology from George Mason University.

Nilanga Jayasinghe, Manager, Asian Species, Wildlife Conservation, WWF-US

Nilanga is a manager on the Wildlife Conservation team and focuses on Asian species, particularly elephants, rhinos, tigers, and snow leopards. She is also the WWF Network lead on Asian elephants and sits on the leadership team of the WWF Network human-wildlife conflict working group. She has more than 20 years of extensive experience in international species conservation and has worked on conservation issues in Asia, Africa, and North America. Nilanga’s areas of expertise include Asian elephants, human-wildlife conflict management, strategic planning, connectivity conservation and sustainable infrastructure, among others. She is also a member of the Asian Elephant Specialist Group , the Asian Rhino Specialist Group, and the Pangolin Specialist Group under the International Union for the Conservation of Nature’s (IUCN) Species Survival Commission, and a member of the Connectivity Conservation Specialist Group under the IUCN’s World Commission on Protected Areas.
